DataElement.preferredName: Head and Neck Surgery Specific Complication Orbital Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the kind of  orbital complication specific to head and neck surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Head and Neck Surgery Specified Complication Orbit
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any surgery involving a structure in the head and neck region._Clearly and explicitly stated._Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure._The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Head and Neck Surgery Specified Complication
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any surgery involving a structure in the head and neck region.:Clearly and explicitly stated.:Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.

Concepts.definition: Any surgery involving a structure in the head and neck region.
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.

Property.preferredDefinition: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

Concepts.definition: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results or effects (does not include CTC Adverse Events) of therapeutic agents or procedures administered to the patient.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for Princess Margaret as requested by D.Laurence. mc 6/15/16

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Injury to the epithelium of the cornea.

Concepts.definition: Injury to the epithelium of the cornea.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Situated outside of the eye.: One of the contractile organs of the body.: Damage inflicted on the body as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.

Concepts.definition: One of the contractile organs of the body.
Damage inflicted on the body as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The presence of air or gas in the subcutaneous tissue of the orbit of the eye.

Concepts.definition: The presence of air or gas in the subcutaneous tissue of the orbit of the eye.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel.: A localized collection of blood, usually clotted, in an organ, space, or tissue, due to a break in the wall of a blood vessel.: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

Concepts.definition: The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel.
A localized collection of blood, usually clotted, in an organ, space, or tissue, due to a break in the wall of a blood vessel.

The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The lack of vision.  It is caused by neurological or physiological factors.

Concepts.definition: The lack of vision. It is caused by neurological or physiological factors.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Weakness or paralysis of at least one of the muscles controlling the movement of the eye. It results from degeneration of the muscles or the neural pathways involved in the eye movement. Representative disorders causing ophthalmoplegia include ocular myopathies and multiple sclerosis.

Concepts.definition: Weakness or paralysis of at least one of the muscles controlling the movement of the eye. It results from degeneration of the muscles or the neural pathways involved in the eye movement. Representative disorders causing ophthalmoplegia include ocular myopathies and multiple sclerosis.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
